title: EXIF metadata not stripped from JPG group logos

profile.name: GitLab
profile.about: A single application for the entire software development lifecycle.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:** When uploading JPEG images as group logos on Gitlab, the EXIF metadata is not removed or changed in any way.

**Description:** When setting up a group on Gitlab, you can upload a logo, and if you upload a JPEG with EXIF metadata on it, it isn't stripped. This can lead to disclosure of location where photo was taken or other personal information by the photo uploader if their group is public, as anyone can download the logo and check the metadata.

## Steps To Reproduce:

1. Upload a testing image w any EXIF tags filled in (you can test with the attached download.jpg image on this report)
2. Make the group public
3. Visit the group page unauthenticated and download the image
4. Use Windows properties tool or any EXIF viewer, check the metadata. Whatever was there when uploaded should be there when downloaded, including the exact file name (though the file name part isn't an actual reportable problem, it's good practice to just encode/make it a random file name in case the user uploading forgets to remove personal information in the file name)

## PoC
Check out my group: https://gitlab.com/gthgh
Try downloading the logo. The metadata for it should show "egginfo" under Copyright.

## Impact

An attacker could download public group logos and find sensitive metadata. Some phones attach metadata with the latitude/longitude of where the photo was taken which could leak important information, and it's just best practice as well to strip all metadata from images when uploaded.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary: When uploading JPEG images as group logos on Gitlab, the EXIF metadata is not removed or changed in any way.

Description: When setting up a group on Gitlab, you can upload a logo, and if you upload a JPEG with EXIF metadata on it, it isn't stripped. This can lead to disclosure of location where photo was taken or other personal information by the photo uploader if their group is public, as anyone can download the logo and check the metadata.

Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Upload a testing image w any EXIF tags filled in (you can test with the attached download.jpg image on this report)
  2. Make the group public
  3. Visit the group page unauthenticated and download the image
  4. Use Windows properties tool or any EXIF viewer, check the metadata. Whatever was there when uploaded should be there when downloaded, including the exact file name (though the file name part isn't an actual reportable problem, it's good practice to just encode/make it a random file name in case the user uploading forgets to remove personal information in the file name)

PoC

Check out my group: https://gitlab.com/gthgh
Try downloading the logo. The metadata for it should show "egginfo" under Copyright.

Impact

An attacker could download public group logos and find sensitive metadata. Some phones attach metadata with the latitude/longitude of where the photo was taken which could leak important information, and it's just best practice as well to strip all metadata from images when uploaded.

additional_data.old_title: EXIF metadata not stripped from JPG group logo photos
additional_data.new_title: EXIF metadata not stripped from JPG group logos

activities.message:
Hi @ghjfgjggfdfhfgsdfssdf,

Thank you for submitting this report. We will investigate the issue as soon as possible.
Due to our current workload, we will get back within 20 business days with an update.

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @ghjfgjggfdfhfgsdfssdf,

activities.message:
Hello,

Thank you for submitting this report.

We have verified this finding and have escalated to our engineering team.  We will be tracking progress internally at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/54220.  This issue will be made public 30 days following the release of a patch.

We will continue to update you via HackerOne as a patch is scheduled for release.

Best regards,
Dennis
Security Team | GitLab Inc.

activities.message: Just wondering why it got pushed back a month after already being 3 months? Thanks
activities.markdown_message: Just wondering why it got pushed back a month after already being 3 months? Thanks

activities.message:
Hi @jack898,

implementing a patch has turned out to require more effort than planned, as we need to address existing uploads as well as new uploads. Given that the severity of this finding is low, we pushed the patch back one month to have the required time for a clean implementation.

You will be able to read up on our design considerations at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/55469. We make the discussion public 30 days after a patch has been released.

Thank you for your patience and please let us know if you have any questions.

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team
activities.markdown_message:

implementing a patch has turned out to require more effort than planned, as we need to address existing uploads as well as new uploads. Given that the severity of this finding is low, we pushed the patch back one month to have the required time for a clean implementation.

You will be able to read up on our design considerations at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/55469. We make the discussion public 30 days after a patch has been released.

Thank you for your patience and please let us know if you have any questions.

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Best regards,
Security Team | GitLab Inc.

activities.message: @dappelt I was just checking back in and this does not appear to be fixed, as you can see [in my group here](https://gitlab.com/gthgh) the metadata is still attached to the logo. I also created an entirely new group and uploaded a logo and it's still there. Unless this resolution was for the issue in a different area of the site, this does not appear resolved.

activities.message:
Hi @jack898,

we only strip metadata that is privacy-relevant. Is there any particular metadata field that you see relevant for privacy?

Best regards,
Dennis
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message: @dappelt Are group logos considered privacy-relevant? Like I say that’s originally what this report was for and it’s still not fixed.

activities.message:
Not all metadata is privacy-relevant. Below is the metadata from your sample picture https://gitlab.com/gthgh. Any data in particular that you are concerned with?

```
ExifTool Version Number         : 11.11
File Name                       : download.jpg
Directory                       : /Users/da/Downloads
File Size                       : 5.7 kB
File Modification Date/Time     : 2019:07:19 12:12:28+02:00
File Access Date/Time           : 2019:07:19 12:12:31+02:00
File Inode Change Date/Time     : 2019:07:19 12:12:30+02:00
File Permissions                : rw-r--r--
File Type                       : JPEG
File Type Extension             : jpg
MIME Type                       : image/jpeg
Exif Byte Order                 : Big-endian (Motorola, MM)
X Resolution                    : 96
Y Resolution                    : 96
Resolution Unit                 : inches
Y Cb Cr Positioning             : Centered
Copyright                       : egg info
Image Width                     : 275
Image Height                    : 183
Encoding Process                : Baseline DCT, Huffman coding
Bits Per Sample                 : 8
Color Components                : 3
Y Cb Cr Sub Sampling            : YCbCr4:2:0 (2 2)
Image Size                      : 275x183
Megapixels                      : 0.050
```

activities.message:
Hi @jackb898,

This disclosure fell through the cracks and was never accepted. Better late than never though. :) I added a note in the summary related to policy changes that happened since this was reported.

Best regards,
Dominic
GitLab Security Team

summaries.content:
Note that this report was submitted 2 ago and reports related to EXIF metadata not being stripped aren't accepted anymore. The policy now states:

> We are aware of ways to bypass the EXIF metadata stripping and intend to improve this, but we don't consider this impactful enough to be eligible for bounty
summaries.content_html:
Note that this report was submitted 2 ago and reports related to EXIF metadata not being stripped aren't accepted anymore. The policy now states:

We are aware of ways to bypass the EXIF metadata stripping and intend to improve this, but we don't consider this impactful enough to be eligible for bounty

summaries.content: I made a bit of a writeup on Exif metadata disclosure on my blog which can be seen [here](https://medium.com/the-volatile-triad/hacking-always-check-out-the-images-99217e6cea). Thank you to the Hackerone triagers and Gitlab team for a smooth reporting process and resolution.
summaries.content_html: I made a bit of a writeup on Exif metadata disclosure on my blog which can be seen here. Thank you to the Hackerone triagers and Gitlab team for a smooth reporting process and resolution.
